dialogue.raw_text: by Gregory Widen 1  EXT. STREET - NIGHT                                               1 Garish purple light spills out of side-street porno houses, illuminating a silhouette, and little else, of a MAN leaning against an alley wall. He is waiting. Another silhouetted FIGURE appears and approaches the first. They size each other up as best they can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : 15  EXT. CONOR'S FAMILY HUTCH - DAY                                 15 A medieval sun beats down on an OLD TRAVELER making his way up the MacLeod home.  Conor's mother, scrubbing clothes in a bucket, smiles in recognition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 17  INT. ANTIQUE SHOP - DAY                                         17 Classy antiques.  Unusual.  Clocks, tables, chests.  Small and personal. Richard Taupin enters and sheds his overcoat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 20  INT. TAVERN                                                     20 An empty mug is set on the counter of a medieval drinking establishment. CLANSMEN, their faces and clothes smudged with a day's work in the fields, relax and enjoy the company of their fellow VILLAGERS. No longer requiring the use of a cane, Conor enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 22  INT. POLICE DEPARTMENT                                          22 The NOISY business-as-usual confusion at the Washington P.D. processing center. Amongst the dinge of CLANGING phones and CLACKING typewriters, a uniformed OFFICER enters something into a computer terminal. Brenna sits perched on a desk nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 39  INT. MEDIEVAL BLACKSMITH SHOP                                   39 A glowing horseshoe HISSES wildly as it slips into a wooden cooling bucket.  Pulling it out with iron tongs, Conor lays it on a counter and pounds it even with a mallet. Sweaty and streaked with dirt, he tosses the mallet aside and walks out into the late afternoon sunshine. 40  EXT. SHOP FRONTAGE - DAY                                        40 Conor leans over a water barrel and dunks his head and arms, cleaning off a day's worth of sweat and grime. JUAN ROMIREZ Stirring up dust with his travelling boots, this Spanish acc- ented man stops at Conor's shop.  He wears a large broad sword strapped to his waist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 43  EXT. POLICE STATION - DAY                                       43 Brenna stops her car in front of the Washington Police Depart- ment.  Getting out of her car she climbs the stairs but stops. After a moment of indecision she changes her mind and returns to her car. 44  INT. BRENNA'S APARTMENT - DAY                                   44 Brenna lowers herself wearily into a chair, rubs her eyes, and stares absently out the window. Reaching across to an end table, she plays back her answering machine. Beep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 45.  INT. CONOR'S HOME - DAY                                        45 This HISS of Brenna's answering machine becomes the HISS of cooking.  Bandaged about the chest, Conor asleep on his cot. Suddenly he sits up.  Sweating.  He looks about the room in confusion as Romirez enters with a plate of food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 46  EXT. CONOR'S VILLAGE - DAY                                      46 Two days later. Nearly healed, Conor and Romirez stand near a quietly moving stream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 61  EXT. GRASSY KNOLL - DAY                                         61 On a clear rise above the village Romirez and Conor spar with swords covered in heavy cloth.  Conor is having difficulty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 68  INT. MUSEUM RESEARCH LIBRARY                                    68 Somewhere in the bowels of the museum, the RESEARCH LIBRARIAN, a wiry young man, sits at his cluttered desk. Brenna looms above him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 73  EXT. ABANDONED GRAVEYARD - DAY                                  73 Crooked tombstones strewn across the bleached ground of a place not beloning to reality. In full medieval tartan, Conor stands against a forceful wind. CRACKS Run the length plain, spewing forth steam and staggering SKELETONS.  There are dozens of them, all carrying their skulls under one arm. The skeletons press forward and trap Conor against the trunk of a dead oak.  The heads break into harsh, demonic LAUGHTER. Conor puts his hands over his ears in pain as the bodies push forward. SCREAMING, he disappears under a mass of gleaming bones. CUT TO: 74  INT. TAUPIN'S WORSTICK HOME                                     74 Taupin wakes from the dream with a SHOUT. He has fallen asleep in a desk chair. Taupin walks to a window and looks out to the green hills.  To the distance. 75  EXT. RURAL ROAD - DAY                                           75 Brenna's sedan shoots down a country highway. 76  INT. SEDAN - DAY                                                76 Checking her rear view mirror, Brenna notices two suspicious FIGURES in a car behind her. 77  EXT. RURAL ROAD - DAY                                           77 Brenna pulls to the side.  The car from behind passes without incident. 78  INT. SEDAN - DAY                                                78 Brenna is driving again.  Listening now to the RADIO, she casts a glance in the mirror.  The same car is behind her. 79  EXT. RURAL ROAD - DAY                                           79 Passing over a rise in the highway, Brenna turns abruptly onto a service road and behind a group of trees. THE OTHER CAR Pauses a moment at the intersection, then drives on. 80  EXT. STOREFRONT - DAY                                           80 Brenna shows the PROPRIETOR the photograph.  He explains something to her. Brenna steps outside the store onto the Main Street of the very small community of Worstick. AT A STREET CORNER Brenna passes a small monument settled in a flower bed.  It has a plaque memorializing five locals murdered in 1931. 81  INT. SEDAN                                                      81 A mile out of town Brenna stops at a farmhouse.  She checks it against the photo she found at Taupin's townhouse.  They match. 82  EXT. FARMHOUSE DOOR - DAY                                       82 Brenna KNOCKS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 88  EXT. FRENCE MILITARY CAMP - DAY                                 88 Conor, now MAJOR DUPONT of the French infantry, pours over battle plans. An AIDE, dressed as Conor-Dupont in 18th century European military garb, enters the command area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 94  EXT. WORSTICK CHURCH (PRESENT DAY)                              94 Richard Taupin sits against the stone of an old Catholic church. Taupin sighs.  A long, weary sigh. 95  INT. TAUPIN'S FARMHOUSE                                         95 Taupin and Brenna sit at a table working on forms. Taupin looks up from his work and studies Brenna's face without malice. 95  EXT. CREEK - DAY                                                95 Brenna and Taupin are taking a walk along the township's outskirts. Crossing a small bridge over a smaller creek, they encounter the elderly caretaker Mr. North and his eight year old GRANDSON. Both with fishing poles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 101  EXT. COLONIAL STYLE HOME - DUSK                               101 Conor and a beautiful young woman, KATHERINE, sit on the porch steps in 1800s period dress.  Other young COUPLES relax nearby enjoying the warm summer's twilight.  Katherine's MOTHER shuffles between the couples offering lemonade, cakes, and the like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 102  INT. WORSTICK TOWN HALL (PRESENT DAY)                         102 An auditorium has been transformed with colored lights and strung paper into a small town party. TEENAGERS in period dress control the floor, dancing to a decidedly un-period ROCK BAND. The OLDER GUESTS are gathered around the punch bowl talking crops or Pennsylvania politics. BRENNA Fitted as well as can be expected in her lace dress, enters with Taupin, himself dressed in a formal suit complete with cape. His clothes fit perfectly. Mr. North, comically dressed as a pirate, greets them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 107  EXT. TURN OF THE CENTURY CEMETARY - DAY                       107 RELATIVES in period dress watch as a family member is lowered into the ground. A very OLD WOMAN stands stoically, supported on both sides by her middle aged SONS.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: MacLeod. The second nods. The first without hesitation raises a sword, the intended thrust interrupted by his own death as the second with a flash of metal severs the agressor's head. 2  INT. HUTCH - MORNING                                              2 A 15th century Scottish home. A haggard WOMAN, her small CHILD clinging to a tattered apron, stands hunched over a glowing hearth.  Her veined hands drag a wooden spoon around and around through a soot-covered pot of grey soup. From an adjoining room CONOR MACLEOD, a young man dressed up in his best traditional Celtic tartan, enters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My, but are you the picture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surveying himself) It's a bit tight. His FATHER enters with a pail of milk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, Conor, how you look a man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you time for some- thing to eat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Mother.  They'll be here shortly. Conor's father looks him over with pride.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your grandfather wore that in his service to the King, and I to fight for the Duke.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Must he go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye.  It is his duty.  All of ours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Ian, he's still but a boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a MacLeod.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be fine Mother. 3  EXT. HUTCH - MORNING                                              3 Several HORSEMEN gallop up through the early morning fog to the cottage door. Conor's father steps out to meet them. 4  EXT. HILLTOP - MORNING                                            4 A massive KNIGHT sits astride his horse, moorish dew cling- ing to his helmet and breastplate.  A CLANSMAN hikes up the heather-carpeted slope to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They march.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is the boy among them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye. 5  EXT. ALLEY - NIGHT                                                5 The second kneels to examine the headless body of the first. With a CLACK a window, high on the alley wall, closes. 6  EXT. HIGHLAND PLAIN - MORNING                                     6 The DUKE is leading a brigade of CLANSMEN out onto the plain. Mounted VASSALS ride back and forth inspecting the line.  The low fog makes it impossible to see beyond a few yards.  There is an erie, smothering silence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Is a bad day for this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 The Duke has been compro- mised.  He will have his due.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 By day's end he will have our heads.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 We ride against the Suther- lands.  That is all that matters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 This makes no sense to me. CONOR And a friend are marching through the moist heather.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The fog is bad.  We cannot even see the sides of our own ranks. Conor's nervousness is showing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this your first?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye. SHOUTING is heard on the plain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's begun. 7  EXT. HILLTOP - MORNING                                            7 The Knight, above the fog, hears the battle commence below. He spurs his horse and starts down into the mist. 8  EXT. PLAIN - MORNING                                              8 The two opposing clans are now one confused mass of tartan and clashing swords.  The air is charged with SHOUTS of ex- citement, agony, and the SHRILL of bag pipes. The fog has made each man's battle his own, each isolated with his opponent. THE KNIGHT Rides calmly through the fracas.  He strikes and kills those that assault him, but appears disinterested in battle. He is looking. CONOR Is standing above the twitching body of his friend. Alone and confused, Conor has become seperated from the clan. He stumbles through the fog, seeking help. Suddenly he is alone with the Knight. The face of iron locks its gaze onto the boy.  His fear turned to panic, Conor turns and flees. The Knight, his resolve steeled in a raised sword, kicks his horse into persuit. Conor is easily overtaken and on his first pass the Knight brings his blade down hard into Conor's shoulder, slicing open most of the boy's back and knocking him face-first into the heather. As Conor watches his own blood spew forth, he rolls over in time to see the Knight dismount and start for him. THE KNIGHT Leans down next to Conor, his metal face nearly against the boy's.  His voice slithers out of the iron in almost a whisper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There can be but one. A CLANSMAN Charges out of the fog and attacks the Knight, who cuts him nearly in half.  ANOTHER wanders in and meets the same fate. The battle is shifting to where they are. Not finished yet with Conor, the Knight is finding himself forced into retreat from an ever increasing number of assail- ants. A VASSAL Sees his men being hacked apart trying to stop the now-mounted Knight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Leave him! The clansmen obey. With the slap of an armored gauntlet against his steed, the Knight disappears into the fog. The Vassal surveys the carnage before him.  His eyes fall a moment on the moaning, gurgling Conor. The Vassal turns and leaves the boy for dead. 9  EXT. ALLEY - NIGHT                                                9 A patrol car pauses at the mouth of the alley. The figure considers his situation, then quickly shoves his sword into a near-by drain.  He straightens up and waits. AN OFFICER Steps out of his unit and cautiously walks forward.  His PARTNER switches on the patrol car's side lamps, bathing the alley in a harsh glare. MAN IN ALLEY For the first time we can see his face.  RICHARD TAUPIN, clad in a well-cut business suit, looks exactly like Conor. The police officer, upon seeing the body, grabs instinctively for his pistol.  He yells to his partner now coming into the alley.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Kevin!  Get is a backup.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was merely walking by when-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Don't move. The officer has his pistol out and leveled. His partner runs up, shotgun in hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 They're on their way. His voice cuts short as the blood flows against his shoe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Christ. 10  INT. HUTCH - NIGHT                                              10 Conor lies moaning on a cot.  Makeshift bandages wrap his body, stained and pasted by thick, dried blood. The family surrounds their dying son. A PRIEST is delivering the last rites.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Libera Domine Animan servi tui sicut libertasi David de manu regis Saul... His sobbing mother holds a compress to Conor's forehead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...In mamus tuas domine commendo spiritum meum... 11  EXT. HUTCH - NIGHT                                              11 A Vassal rides up to the hutch, dismounts, and approaches a CLANSMAN standing in the open doorway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Has the boy died?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is having the last rites now.  It should be over by morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Never seen anybody cut as bad live so long.  He should have died on the field.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tonight or tomorrow, it's all the same. The Vassal peers inside at the priest administering the sacraments.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Auditorium nostrum in nomine domini...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 This has been a dark day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Requiescant in pace... 12  EXT. ALLEY - NIGHT                                              12 There is a bustle of activity.  Setting up barricades, uni- formed OFFICERS are trying to keep NEW CREWS and curious ONLOOKERS at a distance. DETECTIVE LT. MORAN Lean, fortyish, and comfortable with the gore in front of him, is inspecting the corpse with a MEDICAL EXAMINER.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (studying body) Real clean.  No sawing action at all.  Whatever it was did it in one swipe. (looks up at Moran) Like the other one. Moran gestures to a sword, wrapped in plastic, lying nearby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hasn't any blood on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking around) About the only thing that doesn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll give it a closer look when I get back. BRENNA CARTWRIGHT Pretty but not beautiful, thirtyish, she exudes a sort of insolent intelligence. An OFFICER sees her duck under a police barricade.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #3 Come on Brenna, you know better than that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm invited. She walks to where the medical examiner is organizing his equipment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (greeting) Mr. Levine... The examiner turns and smiles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hope this isn't past your bedtime. Brenna looks to the now-sheeted corpse, blood flowing from where the head should be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doesn't have a head, does he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This one came unassembled. Lt. Moran is standing near.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (no warmth) Just show her what she came for, Tom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stands, taps Brenna's arm) Come on, this is more your line of work. Brenna and the examiner walk the few yards from the corpse to the sword.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's your uncle?  I hardly ever see him anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. The examiner stops and gestures to the weapon clothed in forensic plastic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There you go. Brenna's expression changes to interest as she kneels down beside it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't look like it came from "Toys-Are-Us", that's why I called you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks up in Moran's direction) Didn't think it was my buddy over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Figured you knew more about swords than I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Claymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Scottish claymore.  Take a French epee, add twenty pounds of ballast so it means business, and you've got a claymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the expert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (runs hand along hilt, slightly confused) It's in good condition. RICHARD TAUPIN Is being put in the rear of a patrol car.  Brenna studies his face in the half-gloom.  There's something different about him. A steadiness. 13  INT. POLICE INTERROGATION ROOM                                  13 Richard Taupin is seated at a graffitti scrawled table in a room otherwise bare of furnishings.  He seems unphased by his surroundings. The door opens and Moran enters with bag and notebook.  He picks up Taupin's wallet on the table top and checks the driver's license.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This your present address?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr.- (looks at license) Taupin, what were you doing in that alley?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was walking by when I heard a shout.  Your men came right after.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you know the victim?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His name was Iman Fasil if that jogs your memory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It doesn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was carrying a Syrian passport and had been in the country less than a week. Taupin's face is stoic and controlled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two days ago a Bulgarian national was murdered the same way.  He'd also been in the country less than a week. (beat) What is your citizenship?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: American. Moran paces to a corner of the room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you make a habit of hanging out in that neigh- borhood at night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you getting at?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's just say that in my years with this department I've seen more than one well dressed business man look for a hand job on 14th Street. Moran places both hands on the table and leans across it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What were _you_ looking for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's none of your business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're wrong. Moran reaches into a bag on the table and removes a large broad sword; old, but in mint condition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know what this is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I presume it's a sword.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A claymore to be exact.  You wouldn't know anything about it would you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your murder weapon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was covered with Mr. Fasil's fingerprints, but none of his blood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A mystery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For the moment. Moran turns the sword over in his hand then sets it down. He rises and opens the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right Mr. Taupin, we'll be in touch. Taupin passes through the doorway without comment. 14  EXT. POLICE STATION - NIGHT                                     14 Taupin out into the crisp night air.  His eyes search out the darkness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah Steven, it is good to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I only just heard of Conor.  I came up from Catroch as soon as I could.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a kind man to be sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought it only proper to pay me last respects to the family.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Steven, Conor didn't die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I had heard his wounds were mortal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They were Steven, they were.  It's been a miracle it has.  He lasted right through and healed.  No one in the village has ever seen anything like it.  Ever. 16  EXT. MEADOW - DAY                                               16 Perched on a heather-carpeted rise above the village a young woman, MARA, sits contemplating the intricaces of a daffodil. Balancing on a shepard's staff, Conor limps over and puts his lips to her ear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're pretty today. Mara is silent.  Distant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm your future husband, remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have no future husband.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understand.  Not a week ago your father gave us his blessing. This is difficult for her.  Tears well in her eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My future husband died in battle against the Sutherlands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you saying?  I'm standing here as real as you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You cannot be real, Conor.  You had the last rites.  No man has been cut half as bad and lived.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I did live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Live?  In less than a week you're prancing about the country like a squirrel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So why the crazy talk?  It's a miracle it is.  Saint Andrew has smiled on me.  On us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some think not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's rumor in the village. Some call it magic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's mad.  Surely you don't take their word?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, Conor.  It's not natural.  Maybe something has touched you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're sounding like that mad woman, Widow Baggins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me father has taken back my hand. He puts a hand to her cheek.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, Lassie... She steps back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please not be touching me, Conor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll not take that kind of talk from you.  From those others below, maybe.  But not from you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave me alone, Conor.  Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not talking sense, Mara! Anger tumbles into exasperation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. He steps for her.  She moves away.  Conor's face hardens with resentment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you send me away now, Mara, I'll not come looking for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crying) Do what you must. Resigned, Conor turns and limps away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Thompson agreed to settle for fifteen, Melvin's wants to make a pick-up at three o'clock, the coffee machine's broken, and there's a Miss Cartwright from the Smithsonian in your office. Taupin is hardly in the mood. 18  INT. TAUPIN'S OFFICE                                            18 Brenna Cartwright stands in Taupin's cluttered surroundings admiring a bagpipe set neatly on a shelf.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you play?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very traditional. Taupin sits down and begins sorting through a stack of papers on his desk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatient) Miss Cartwright, what is it I can do for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to ask you about the claymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's quite rare you know, some- thing so common in its time so well looked after all these years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Cartwright, unless you have come here to sell the sword, there's very little I can help you with.  Now if you will excuse me, I have a great deal of work to do. Brenna has taken a carving from the shelf.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Byzantine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Basil the II.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charming guy, Basil.  Once after beating an army of Serbians he blinded all but-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: -All but one out of a hundred, I know.  All left to be led like donkeys back home.  Now if you will please- Brenna suddenly tosses the carving at him.  Taupin snatches it out of the air with lightning precision.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good reflexes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good day, Miss Cartwright. 19  INT. SMITHSONIAN MUSEUM DEPARTMENT OFFICE                       19 A lonely, ancient room full of equal parts dust and oaken study tables. The department SUPERVISOR sits at his desk surrounded by a handful of his staff RESEARCHERS - Brenna included.  A faded, stern portrait of some forgotten curator presides over propped up feet, cold coffee, and half eaten sack lunches.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't believe him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Requiem acer'nam donaei-

His mother, tears on her cheek, hugs him tightly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please take care of yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye. Conor turns to his father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish there was some other way. They clasp hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Conor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye. Without looking back he passes through the doorway and down the empty path, his figure quickly fading in the moorish fog.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is against the rules.

dialogue.raw_text: So's playing choo-choo with two high school cheerleaders in the middle of-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: -Okay okay.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Church Hill, that's pretty close, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything in Maryland is close. 23  EXT. GEORGETOWN STREET - DAY                                    23 Taupin steps out of a Metro station and walks the few blocks to his brick townhouse.  Climbing the front stairs, he fishes his keys out of a coat pocket.  About to insert the key he stops, sensing something. Backing down the steps, Taupin slips around to the rear of the building. 24  INT. TAUPIN HOME                                                24 Like a spider Taupin pries open a window and slips silently inside. The home is dark and still. Taupin creeps down the hallway and peers into the entryway. There a MAN, dressed in a tuxedo jacket and nearly imperceptible in the dim light, is crouched at the front door. He is holding a sword. Taupin removes a knife from his pocket and JUMPS the intruder. The two STRUGGLE fiercely. Taupin pins the intruder against the carpet and shoves his knife firmly against the man's throat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is he? Bulging eyes stare at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What name is he using? Taupin presses the blade.  A trickle of blood rolls down the throat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Smith.  Carl Smith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many came?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The last four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the Bulgarian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He got him. (hoarse chuckle) He always does.  Eventually.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He knows I'm here.  How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: None of this would be happening if you hadn't run... The knife is pressed deeper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: _Answer_ me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gasping) We learned he'd found the immigration notaries in Liverpool and traced them to New York.  Then he figured out the birth records in Church Hill... 25  EXT. RURAL HIGHWAY - DAY                                        25 A city limit sign announcing the small community of Church Hill is overtaken by Brenna's sedan. 26  EXT. ROADSIDE CAFE TELEPHONE BOOTH - DAY                        26 Brenna looks through a telephone book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Taupin...Taupin... Nothing.  She closes the book and drums her fingers on the cover. 27  EXT. COUNTY RECORDS OFFICE - DAY                                27 An 1860s stone columned affair, far more impressive than the low-lying town that surrounds it. Brenna enters. 28  INT. COUNTY RECORDS OFFICE                                      28 Brenna sits sifting through a large cloth-bound book entitled _Certificates of Birth: 1941-1948_.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) Tarmin...Tatum...Taupin, Richard Marshall.  Born to William and Karen Taupin, no address.  Attend- ing physician, Dr. Willis Kidell. 29  INT. DR. KIDELL'S HOME                                          29 Dr. Kidell stands at his bookcase leafing through a binder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: that strains the memory. (after a fashion) Here we are, Richard Taupin. He carries the binder to the table where Brenna sits.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you like more tea?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No thank you, I'm fine. Kidell sips his own and looks over the binder page.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was unsual.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, this is a small town, and it was even smaller then.  Most all the babies I delivered were from local families.  Richard's parents were just passing through when his mother's time came.  I did it right here at the house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you didn't know Richard later on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been trying to find somebody who knew him and any connections his family might have had with museums or historical societies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't know about any of that. Suppose nobody does.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't follow you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Poor little tyke didn't have a chance.  Hopelessly premature.  He died a few days after he was born.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The boy _died_?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mother too.  Sad case it was.  The young lady just couldn't make it through labor.  Never even saw her son. Dr. Kidell removes from the binder a tattered newspaper clipping.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My brother worked for the town paper at the time.  He took this picture of the funeral. Something in the clipping sparks Brenna's interest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you spoken to anyone else about this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was this one fella.  Asked a lot of questions.  I was out of town but I heard he spent near a full day in the records office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you remember his name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinks) Carl Smith. 30  INT. POLICE STATION                                             30 A police line-up. Seven MEN, all dressed in Santa Claus outfits with bare legs, are paraded for a small, old LADY.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just tell us when you see the one. Several rows back in the dark sits Brenna's UNCLE JOE, the district attorney, and another man, his ASSISTANT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just curious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're never "just curious". (to assistant) You've met my neice, Brenna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi Brenna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to line-up) Number 5, lift your coat up more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't you getting a little old for this?  You flunked out of law school.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rolls her eyes) Now there's a new topic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't they have enough for you to do at the castle? Brenna puts on her best little-girl angelic smile, a smile her uncle can never refuse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) Forgers do it all the time.  They take the birth certificate of some- one who died young and use it to get legit I.D.  Usually they carry it long enough to pass some bad checks then dump it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call your mother.  You never call her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to old lady) Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.  I'd have to see his thing. 31  INT. BRENNA'S BEDROOM - NIGHT                                   31 A swath of moonlight shines in across a carafe-turned-vase, a New England college diploma, and a police uniform hanging from the bedpost where Brenna lies with another man, DENNIS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't figure out why he's doing it. He's been Richard Taupin at least since 1967.  And the guys rich.  You should see the stuff he has in that shop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe he's hiding from something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some guy named Smith was asking about him in Church Hill.  I passed his name around with your buddies downtown but they drew a blank.  So he isn't a cop.  District anyway. Dennis gets out of bed and begins putting on his uniform.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably just some exec ducking an ex-wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Kidell had a picture in his file of the funeral.  The father looked just like Richard.  Even had a mark on his cheek.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How old is Richard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: .D. says 41, but he barely looks
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Congeniality?  Let him find his own clues.  There's a journal article in this somewhere.

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the cream of society awaits. (cocks hat to one side) If you're ever in the neighborhood...

The glowing Jefferson Memorial can be seen in the distance. DETECTIVE MORAN Is supervising.  An OFFICER climbs up the embankment to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They found it. The officer leads him down to the river where a headless BODY wearing a tuxedo jacket is being put into a plastic bag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was about fifty yards down- stream from the head. Moran looks down at the body bag, its dark plastic reflecting the rythmic rotation of squad car beacons.

Driving the steed hard through the course, Taupin pulls firm on the reins, bringing horse and rider to a shuddering stop where Detective Moran waits.

dialogue.raw_text: There's been another murder. Taupin lifts his eyes to the suburban treeline.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My condolences.

dialogue.raw_text: Where were you Tuesday night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A neighbor saw your car leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue
