dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got all the time in the world. (looks at watch) Except right now.  If you will excuse me, Lieutenant. In no hurry, Taupin leads his horse away. 34  INT. MUSEUM RESEARCH DEPARTMENT                                 34 Brenna sits surrounded by books of old English law, colorful family banner plates, and a medieval caltrap sitting on her desk corner. Boring quickly, she shuts the book and sighs.  From another folder she pulls out a computer sheet. INSERT COMPUTER SHEET The police sheet has Taupin's name and motor vehicle record. Below are listed four WILLIAM TAUPINS, their hometowns and driving records.  Richard Taupin's first driver permit was in 1967. Brenna looks down the list to a WILLIAM TAUPIN of Felton, Delaware, who stopped filling for driver permits in 1967, the year Richard started. 35  EXT. GAS STATION - DAY                                          35 Dropping a couple of quarters into a vending machine, Brenna removes and opens up a map of the State of Delaware. 36  EXT. GRAVEYARD - DAY                                            36 Brenna steps out of her car at a small town cemetary. Holding a slip of paper, she weaves her way through the shade covered tombs of revolutionary heroes and their descendants. On a small rise fresh dirt lies in careless piles around an open grave. Richard Taupin stands at the mouth of the pit. A coffin has been brutally pulled from the dirt and lies open and propped diagonally beside a marker that reads: "WILLIAM MICHAEL TAUPIN". The casket is empty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone beat you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you taken to touring small town cemetaries, Miss Cartwright?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grave robbers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People like that rarely leave business cards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does Carl Smith? A flash of interest, quickly suppressed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what you're talking about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you do.  Better yet, I don't think anything was stolen because nothing was there in the first place. And I think Mr. Smith, whoever he is, now knows that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have an active imagination.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been to Church Hill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Cartwright, you are involving yourself in matters that do not concern you.  I strongly suggest you return to Washington and stay out of small town cemetaries. He starts for the gate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could find him. Taupin stops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I doubt that. (beat) Good day, Miss Cartwright. He walks on. After only a few paces Taupin suddenly shudders to an abrupt stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong? He holds up an open palm to silence her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your help may be unneccessary. The air is still. Taupin's face is expressionless.  He listens intently.  Sensing. An unseen voice rides seemingly on the wind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (o.s.) Good afternoon, "Mr. Taupin". Taupin whirls around to see a large man standing with broad sword in hand.  We have never seen the knight out of his armor before, but this man certainly seems to fit the bill.  Wearing Levis and leather jacket in contrast to Taupin's expensive business suit, he speaks with icy evenness from a face of stone. Taupin, naked without his own sword, is trapped against a marble wall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not so long. The Knight is closing in on him, sword gripped in both hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been here from the start.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My quarry grows clever with age.  And the others, incompetent. The Knight throws Brenna a glance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Friend of yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of sorts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do hope she enjoys a good show. The Knight leans his whole body into a two-fisted swing, clanging out a chunk of marble as Taupin ducks. A second swipe also imbeds itself in stone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So now it ends. A thrust cuts only air.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Generation upon generation. Tens of thousands of miles. Taupin leaps behind a tree.  The Knight cuts it nearly in half.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the last, MacLeod. Romirez, Lacroux, Neuvich, those fools that followed me, their heads all line my shelf.  All but yours. Taupin drops to the ground in a shoulder roll to avoid a swipe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you feel it, MacLeod? Can you _feel_ it! Taupin grabs a tree branch and raps the Knight on the knee, knocking him over. The Knight quickly rights himself and cuts the branch from Taupin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There can be but one. He raises his blade. An elderly WATCHMAN, shotgun cradled in his arms, stands in the clearing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey!  What's going on here? The Knight pauses a split second then with decision launches his sword spear-style firmly into the watchman's chest. Taupin pushes past him to Brenna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Run! Brenna is frozen in shock. Taupin shoves her roughly toward the gate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Run!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! The Knight retrieves his sword from the watchman's body and lumbers after them. Taupin and Brenna bolt from the cemetary and into the surround- ing residential area. 37  EXT. RESIDENTIAL STREET - DAY                                   37 Taupin leads an exhausted Brenna in a gallop down the side- walk. They have apparently lost the Knight.  Taupin pauses at a corner.  He sees a church across the street. 38  INT. CHURCH                                                     38 Brenna enters and collapses into a pew, her labored breathing echoing off the high ceiling. Taupin walks the length of an aisle to see that they are alone. Satisfied, he leans against a banister and considers his sit- uation. Trying to recover her wind, Brenna has her eyes closed and head against the back of the pew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus Christ.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll be safe here.  He won't kill in a church.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distracted) Tradition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell is going on? Taupin stares out the window, stained glass shining orange on his face.  He looks at Brenna briefly, then passes through the Church's doorway without a word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your name is Conor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bows slightly) Juan Cid Romirez.  Chief surveyor and alchemist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (notices accent) You're not from these parts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am from Spain.  And I would like a moment of your time. 41  INT. CONOR'S HOME                                               41 Romirez is seated at a table.  His back to the Spaniard, Conor is preparing some food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't much to offer, Mr. Romirez from Spain, but you're welcome to what's here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please go to no trouble. Romirez is looking at the faint, pale hint of a scar that runs from Conor's shoulder blade to his waist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your back, it would seem perhaps you were injured in battle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five years past me clan fought another over some- thing I cannot even re- member.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your marks would suggest great injury.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was nearly killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you lived. Conor looks up from his work in pained memory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did at that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And but for a mark you are well as any man, no?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should imagine that your recovery must have alarmed your fellow villagers, perhaps giving them reason to invent an explanation.  And a solution. Something isn't right. Conor turns and faces him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was driven out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And now you live in a small village miles away from all you knew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can you know this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tone lightens) First food, no?  A good meal makes conversation so much easier. Stunned with the implications of what Romirez has said, like a robot Conor serves the meal.  His eyes never leave Romirez, who digs hungrily into the food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmm, que rico.  What is it you call this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pheasant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You Scots have a way with game.  It still has life in it. Spirit.  Back home the food is so...domestic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was sent by his majesty of Spain to Inverness as a con- sultant on matters of metal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a long way from Inverness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In my travels I heard the story of the MacLeod boy struck down and brought from the hand of death by powers not of this Earth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know me home.  Me name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was time for our paths to cross. Romirez pulls back the sleeve on his cloak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see this? He traces some discoloration on his arm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I was a boy a cart driven by a drunken fool crushed me.  All thought I would die or be maimed for life.  But I healed quickly. And like you I paid the price for being different.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are the same?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you ever feel a flow, as if some- thing were pushing against you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.  Always.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does it change with me in the room?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is less.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You feel you know me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are brothers. 42  EXT. VILLAGE - NIGHT Romirez and Conor walk alone amongst torch-lit hutches.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He told me there could be only one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some cling to sanity through time with the one continuity and trad0 ition their lives have known: The Game. (Conor confused) You and I Conor, we are different from all others around us.  You know this, you can feel it.  We are flesh and bone like any man, but unlike our neighbors we are rather difficult to injure, (looks away) permanently.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are still so very young.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm twenty-two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes head) Not even a single lifetime. Romirez chooses his words very carefully.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Conor, you and I, we cannot be killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are immortal. Stunned, Conor backs away from Romirez.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, that can't be. Romirez grasps Conor's shoulder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is as you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pushes away) No! This is all too much for Conor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to me.  Hear the words.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is madness!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! Romirez suddenly draws his sword and thrusts it into Conor's heart.  The boy's mouth drops open in shocked terror as his eyes roll up into his head. A shudder, then Conor slides off the blade and crashes to the ground.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Dr. Wickland at GWU.  Your test came back today.  You can call me here at the med center if you have any questions. Click. Beep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brenna, where the hell are you? The place is full of cops asking weird questions.  What's going on? I've got work stacking up.  Get in here right away. Brenna stands and goes to the kitchen, returning with a glass of wine. Click. Beep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brenna. She freezes in her tracks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My quarrel is not with you.  Meet me. Brenna's eyes are glued on the machine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have much to talk of, you and I.  Answers for the young historian. (beat) O'Reily's.  Tonight.  I've grown to like taverns. Click. Beep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Happy birthday to you, happy birth- day to you, happy birthday dear Brenna, happy birthday to you. Brenna is still upset from the last call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi Brenna, it's mom.  Me and your neices just wanted to call and wish you a happy birthday.  Crissy made a real cute card for you, be sure to call her.  Will you be home for Easter?  Call when you can.  Love you. Click. Hiss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Three days you've laid there. It's time you ate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dazed) This can't be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are not dead, boy.  Accept it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is monstrous.  I'll burn in hell for all eternity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd have to die first. (extends forkful of food) Aqui. Conor starts CRYING.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is to become of me?  Am I to wander the Earth forever like a ghost?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will live.  Survive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then they were right.  I am evil. This is God's punishment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have done nothing wrong Conor MacLeod.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my God.  Oh my God I'm lost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why does he want to kill me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You recall how I spoke of the push you feel and how I make it less?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is always less with my living. Far or near.  But if I were to die the push would become stronger than ever before.  There is power in this.  And as long as you and I live, The Knight can never have it all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But we cannot be killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is an imperfection.  For all your healing, if your head ever leaves your neck, you are dead. You can survive anything but steel against your threat.  Then it is over.  The end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can I stop such a man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hide.  Run to the ends of the Earth till you learn.  You must learn to defend yourself.  In this I can help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are brothers.  And you are a defense- (beat) -of sorts. 47  EXT. PENNSYLVANIA FARMHOUSE - DAY                               47 An old man, MR. NORTH, leads Taupin up the drive of a rural farmhouse somewhere in the hinterland of Pennsylvania.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH When your father died I saw to it that the grounds were kept up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The money in the estate was enough to cover your costs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Oh yes, more than enough. 48  INT. FARMHOUSE                                                  48 Furniture clad in white sheets.  Dust everywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Most of the furniture was put into protective storage.  I'll have some boys come up and clean the place out for you. Taupin drags a finger across a dusty window pane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH (fascinated) You're one of William's kids, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His only kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Sure take after him.  Never seen a father and son look more alike.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We were very close.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH The resemblance is amazing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When may I expect the cleaners?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH I'll send them right up. 49  INT. "O'REILY'S" - NIGHT                                        49 Coupled strangers gyrate under colored lights and recorded music. Brenna sits alone.  Whatever nervousness she brought through the door with her has been turned into a comfortable cynicism by the three empty glasses in front of her. A MAN With something less than perfect coordination, sits down beside her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That stuff'll put you away if you're not careful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was a Count.  Count Dusan.  He would invite the local peasants to his chateau, fill them full of wine, then slice their bellies so he could reuse it. (smiles) The symmetry of that somehow always appealed to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're very macabre.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's my birthday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Happy birthday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. Brenna drains her glass and sets it down with a sigh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Buy a birthday girl a drink? 50  INT. PUB - NIGHT                                                50 A small neighborhood tavern.  Regulars chat amicably with the BARTENDER-OWNER. TAUPIN Sits alone at a corner table.  A WAITRESS hovers over him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lager and lime. LATER Taupin's lager is drained.  Lost in thought, he drags a finger around and around the lip of the mug. He hand stops.  It twitches.  Shakes. Taupin pulls his hand from the glass and watches it shake slightly out of control.  A warning. He WHIRLS around suddenly to see LING KAHN, Asian, standing over him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: MacLeod. Taupin is anxious, poised for attack. Kahn breaks into a broad smile.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Spare a chair?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kahn?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you going to offer me a chair or leave me standing here all night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit. Kahn takes his place across the table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (unsure) How are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Head still secure to the neck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you find me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many places this side of the Atlantic serve lager and lime? Taupin looks to his own glass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Old habits die hard. (to waitress) Waitress!  A round of Nitzhic! (beat) Peasant drool, I know.  But it's the closest thing they stock to my side of the fence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is the gathering, my friend.  The settling of old scores. Taupin tenses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And have you something to settle with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Not tonight.  Tonight I have a drink with an old friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's good to see you, Kahn. The waitress sets down two glasses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come, toast with me the past. (raises glass) To old conquests, old loves, and to a time when we cared about either. Kahn drains his glass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Waitress! 51  EXT. THE WASHINGTON MALL - NIGHT                                51 Kahn and Taupin sit drunkedly on the marble steps of a closed government building.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll never forget the look on that Papal commander's face when his "heretic stronghold" turned out to be a rock full of whores climbing all over Neuvich.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Neuvich, the clown of the crusades.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But then rides up Pope Pius who calmly brushes the dust from his papal cross, climbs off his papal horse, draws his papal sword and asks just what the hell is going on.  And what did Neuvich, dear dear drunken Neuvich do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Offered the Pope one of his whores. They LAUGH. A JOGGER stops on the gravel and listens to the strange conversation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Had a great swing with his blade. For a Pope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) Good times then.  A man could stretch his legs without bring- ing half the world down around his ears.  Not like now. The jogger shakes his head and runs on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (serious) He found us even there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He always did. 52  EXT. ZOO - NIGHT                                                52 A CLINKING of chain link as Taupin and Kahn climb a fence and tumble into the Washington Zoo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't drunk this much since-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: -Since you last saw me. Kahn chucks an empty wine bottle.  An unspecified animal GROWLS sleepily somewhere in the darkness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. 53  EXT. DISPLAY AREA - NIGHT                                       53 Taupin and Kahn stumble through an open-air display of Asian animals.  Their VOICES seem to echo everywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love zoos.  Ever since I was a kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were never a kid. Kahn leans on the wall of a water buffalo pen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (points at one) I knew his great-grandfather.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're insane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, seriously.  We used to shoot pool together in Rangoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do it, Kahn?  How do you live so full of life for so long?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tasting and enjoying life is the only thing of value we have.  All else is just marking time. (beat) You're marking time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've had a few more concerns. Kahn jams his hands into his overcoat and starts down the footpath.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The pressure only comes when you let the taste slip into your mouth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't run as hard, MacLeod. You just don't run as hard anymore. 54  INT. O'REILY'S - NIGHT                                          54 Late.  The bar is nearly empty. No sign of the Knight.  Brenna looks at her watch, sighs, and drops a bill onto the counter. 55  EXT. STREET - NIGHT                                             55 Brenna has left the bar and is now walking down a dimly lit street. She hears something and turns. -Nothing.  A breeze rustles the trees above. After only a few more paces she hears something again. Brenna abruptly turns. -Right into the face of THE KNIGHT. Brenna SCREAMS.  The Knight reaches into his leather carrying bag. A GROUP OF NOISY TEENAGERS Exit a facing townhouse.  The Knight removes his hand from the bag as they spill onto the sidewalk LAUGHING and YELLING. Brenna moves close to the group as they walk to the corner. The Knight follows at a measured distance. At the corner the teenagers climb into a pickup and drive off. Brenna bolts into the intersection.  Weaving through SCREECHING brakes, she disappears into a pair of lighted glass doors. 56  INT. BUILDING                                                   56 40 well dressed PATRONS, numbered cards pinned to their lapels, sit in velvetly plush surroundings.  At the front of the room stands a thin moustached art AUCTIONEER. Brenna BUSTLES in from outside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I apoligize for the lateness of the hour, but I'm sure you will all agree the quality of this year's collection is well worth the time. The Knight BURSTS in with his leather carrying bag.  Brenna slides along the draped back wall to avoid him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (holding statuette) For this fine example of medieval religious art, let us open the bid at 4,000 dollars. The Knight closes in on Brenna casually, without hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: once, 10,500 twice... Brenna raises her arm to attract the attention of a SECURITY GUARD..
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (points at Brenna)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: .  A bid at 11,000.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I- The guard notices she has no lapel number and starts for her very officially. Being closed in on from both sides, Brenna suddenly runs across the room to a fire exit, setting off an ALARM as she flies open the door. The Knight leaps after her, knocking over an OLD WOMAN in the front row. 57  EXT. BUILDING - NIGHT                                           57 Brenna runs the sidewalk and disappears into a Metro station. 58  INT. METRO STATION                                              58 Brenna runs down the platform and jumps into a subway car just as the doors shut. THE KNIGHT is also now on the platform but can only watch Brenna through a window as the train pulls away. 59  EXT. TAUPIN'S TOWNHOUSE - DAY                                   59 Brenna KNOCKS at the front door.  No answer. She KNOCKS harder.  The unlatched door pushes open. 60  INT. TOWNHOUSE                                                  60 Brenna stands in the doorway. Before her is a disaster.  Furniture has been smashed like matchsticks.  A desk drawer's contents lie strewn in piles on the floor. Brenna enters slowly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Taupin?  I have to talk to you. Nothing has been left unturned or unbroken. Brenna kneels and sifts through a pile of crumpled papers. She comes across an old black and white photograph.  Badly streaked and faded, it shows Taupin standing beside a farm- house.  Written in the corner is "Worstick, 1928". Brenna slips the photo into her pocket.  Standing, she turns smack into Taupin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finished? He looks past her to the destruction of his living room.  It doesn't seem to surprise him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He tried to kill me last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dupont Circle. Taupin sifts through the debris, selecting articles from it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the moment?  Carl Smith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you? He ignores the question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What will you do now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You needn't worry Miss Cartwright. I've been at this a very long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He called you "MacLeod".
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not your concern.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I left a man dead in Felton.  But you don't really care, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That bothers you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was innocent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's dead.  Whatever I may or may not feel means exceedingly little to him now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a witness to a murder.  That seems to put me pretty high on your friend's chop list.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you gone to the police?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?  I'm sure they'd love to hear your story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd rather hear yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) You are being foolish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a historian, Mr. Taupin. Only once in a lifetime do you stare history in the face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go home. He walks to the doorway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why does he want to kill you? Taupin stops, his back to her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He sees me as a threat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you? Taupin walks out the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Concentrate! Conor thrusts.  Romirez blocks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Harder.  Concentrate harder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me arm hurts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Again.  Try again. Conor strikes.  Romirez easily blocks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Harder!  You swing like an impotent cow!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go to hell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, the boy has a mouth, now if only he had an arm. Ticked off, Conor leans himself into a two-fisted swing. Romirez knocks it aside, but Conor recovers faster than he, knocking Romirez flat on his back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Impotent cow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Muy Bien! Conor drops the sword and wipes the sweat from his face. Romirez pours wine from a leather bag into a goblet pulled from his belt.  He offers it to Conor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here my boy, from vineyards as sweet and smooth as a young girl's thigh. Conor accepts the cup.  Romirez pulls himself to his feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It will take less effort as you learn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's like to kill me first. Romirez puts his arm around Conor and refills his cup.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have a gift.  One you must protect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what is this great gift that cannot be seen or smelt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Fabric of life.  The spark that allows the passing of existence from one generation to another.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes head) If that was meant to be an ex- planation Mr. Romirez from Spain, I'm afraid you've failed. Romirez put his arm around Conor and leads him away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come.  Enough sword play for an afternoon. 62  EXT. COUNTRYSIDE - DAY                                          62 A friendly horse race.  Their reflections bouncing off a clear glen, Conor and Romirez dodge moss-laiden ruts and leap fallen tree trunks. Beaming, Conor pushes through a last turn and stops to wait for Romirez, several lengths behind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Romirez rides up) You're no match for Scot, Mr. Romirez.  We're raised as riders.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Point conceeded, Mr. MacLeod. Both their eyes turn to the beauty in view.  Romirez pulls a leaf from a tree and studies it closely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is the fascinatioon?  It is only a leaf.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All living things pay dues, Conor.  They must be respected for that. He pulls the leaf's points from the stalk, one by one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As they age they contribute to a sum that is the kindling from which all future life comes.  To feel it, to know it, is to be in touch with the will of every living thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do not think I like the sound of that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It does not feel nearly as frightening as it sounds.  But the consequences of such feelings can be very frightening. For it gives you great strength.  The strength of _knowledge_.  The ability to stand between the giving of what has always been to what will always be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel hardly nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have not been fully trained. But you will learn.  And you will be good, I can feel that.  You have apt- itude.  This is why our friend is so concerned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But why be so concerned about me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This power is divided amongst you, me, and others like cuts in a pie. But the cuts are not equal.  Some, like you and he, have more.  Much more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am a small player.  But if by helping you I can keep that monster from being the last, then perhaps my life has meant something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am not ready for this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must be.  You have responsibilities. You must learn the rules.  You can never attract attention to yourself, never show the side that will draw others to you.  You will always know when you are in the presence of another.  Beware. But more importantly Conor MacLeod, will be your battle against time.  In the coming years you will see kingdoms rise then rot like wheat.  People will become a transitory, pathetic lot.  The only constant you will know will be the others and the tradition their greed and quest represent.  But life without morality, without the ability to truly taste the sweetness of wine and love, is no life at all.  That is how the others exist.  Nothing more than walking corpses living only to slaughter each other in an insane quest to be the last.  Keep your soul sewed to the earth.  Do not become one of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are young, inexperienced.  You do not know what time can do.  How it can sap all pity, all love.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is not me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With the proper tools, Conor, a naive man can be much more dangerous than an evil one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Conor! A VILLAGER approaches from across the pasture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Darin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hate to be bothering you like this, but me mare threw a shoe. Conor looks to Romirez.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead, Senor. (gestures to wine) I have my friend to keep me company.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be back when I can. Conor sets off across the pasture. 64  INT. CONOR'S HOME                                               64 Romirez enters and flops onto a cot. Settling down for a nap, he sets his sword beneath the bed and closes his eyes to the distant sound of CHILDREN playing. The room is still. Romirez begins to drowse. Suddenly his eyes leap open with full alertness. His hand moves under the cot. With an EXPLOSION the front door is lifted from its hinges and splintered into fragments.  Passing through a cloud of sawdust enters the Knight.  Without pause he topples a kitchen shelf onto a supine Romirez.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Romirez.  What a surprise. Romirez is struggling under the debris. The Knight thrusts hard onto an exposed leg. The limb is severed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madonna! The Knight begins casting aside the shelving. With lightning speed Romirez pulls the sword from beneath the bed and hammers it deep into the Knight's side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bastard! He crashes back against the wall. Romirez tries to lift himself from the bed using his sword as a crutch. The Knight has regained a meager balance on his knees. Blood pours from the slice in his stomach, Romirez pushes himself across the bed, plants his sword into the floor and hobbles a few paces before collapsing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Santa Maria! The Knight crawls across the bed and drops to his knees beside Romirez.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why run?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Demonio! The Knight's trembling hands raise his shaking sword high.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To hell with you. 65  EXT. BARNYARD - DAY                                             65 Conor pounds at a horseshoe. The hammer slips from his grasp as he slumps forward as if pushed. 66  EXT. CONOR'S HOME - DAY                                         66 Badly wounded, the Knight staggers through the shattered doorway and tumbles into the street. A CHILD SCREAMS. Pulling himself up, the Knight hobbles away. 67  EXT. - DAY                                                      67 Conor is running through the village. 67  INT. CONOR'S HOME                                               67 Conor rushes in and shudders to a stop. An entire wall is showered with blood. Conor walks slowly forward.  Dazed. As he looks down something takes his attention. It is Romirez's severed head. Conor moans in anguish and drops to his knees on the blood- stained floor. His head sinks to his chest as he begins sobbing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on Brenna, your ass is already in a sling, don't drag me into it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I need is for you to check the name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You talked to your supervisor lately?  He's burning up the place about you just dropping out of sight.  That on top of the cops bugging him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take care of that Corey, but I need this now. The librarian looks her over skeptically.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Corey, you _owe_ me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's that important?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. The librarian reluctantly reaches for his keys. 69  INT. STORAGE AREA                                               69 Holding Brenna's photograph, the research librarian is comb- ing through stained binders.  The room is old, disorganized, and gives the impression that every fact worth knowing must be in it somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wilson know about this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm doing it on my own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good way to lose your job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some job.  Card filing and cabinet dusting.  Four years in this dump and I haven't written anything for Wilson that a wounded yak couldn't do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I liked the bit you did about Baltic chastity belts. Too bad no one else did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's bullshit.  Everything. My job, the people I get involved with, I'm up to here with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You always were hard to impress. The librarian pulls a binder and opens it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not who.  What.  Worstick's a town in Pennsylvania. 70  INT. MUSEUM RESEARCH OFFICE                                     70 Brenna enters and sits at her desk.  She is looking for something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (confused) Chris, have you seen my notebook? Chris is seated at the desk next to her.  He points at the supervisor's door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, that son of a bitch. 71  INT. MUSEUM SUPERVISOR'S OFFICE                                 71 The high backed office chair is spun away from an angry, entering Brenna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong Wilson, huh?  Not enough excitement in your own desk?  What the hell were you looking for in mine? The chair turns.  Detective Moran, not her supervisor, leafs through her notebook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You better have a warrant.  That's my notebook, you've got no right to be sticking your fingers into it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got a morgue filling up with bodies.  That's my right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want from me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the man of the hour that we all would like to talk to about now has apparently skipped town. (looks at notebook) And all of a sudden the Smithsonian's ambulence chaser is an expert on missing persons. Brenna lifts the telephone receiver.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm calling an attorney.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You and I should talk first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've got nothing to say. Moran presses the post on the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to tell them?  That you're protecting a man who's killed four people?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All fashionably without heads.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Spare me the details.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But there's more.  Wednesday someone played javelin with the cemetary curator in Felton, Delaware.  Some locals spotted two cars with D.C. plates and surprise surprise, they turn out to be registered to our own Brenna Cartwright and the ever popular Richard Taupin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you getting at, Moran?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been a busy little beaver. Especially with that records mess up in Church Hill. (looks at notebook) Your notes are very complete. Naturally my feelings were crushed when you didn't rush right over and tell us what you knew. (looks up) In fact, we're considering book- ing the ambulence chaser as an accessory to murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It'll never stick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But we might just give it the 'ole college try.  What with the court back ups, it could be days before you got an arraignment. But then, I'm sure the flunk-out neice of the D.A. knows all about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're an asshole, Moran.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want Taupin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What makes you so sure he's the one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just for laughs we raided wonder boy's house.  There was a gallon of one of the corpse's blood in his carpet.  I think it was about then I withdrew his name for humanitarian of the year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's all of this got to do with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What were you doing in Felton?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Research.  If your pal was there I never saw him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have witnesses that can put the two of you together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (knows he's bluffing) Never take up poker, Detective.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be stupid, lady.  Your neck can be sliced as fast as anyone else's. Brenna reaches across and lifts her notebook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you wait until it comes out in paperback? Moran watches her leave.  He lifts the telephone receiver. RESEARCH OFFICE Striding out into the corridor, Brenna passes Dennis, the cop from her bedroom, leaning against the doorway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I warned you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go to hell. 72  INT. CHURCH (WASHINGTON D.C.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: celebrates mass in a present-day cathedral. In the rear of the church apart from the other PARISHIONERS sits the Knight.  As the priest leads the parishioners through the procession of faith, the Knight alone repeats it quietly to himself in Latin, the ancient language of the church.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You shouldn't have come. Brenna whirls around and sees Taupin behind her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're you followed? He looks to the road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one knows you're here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  I had to talk to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You had to do _nothing_!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a fool.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe. Pause.  Taupin strides through the doorway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come inside. 83  INT. FARMHOUSE                                                  83 Brenna and Taupin enter.  A heavy broad sword sits on the coffee table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this what you killed them with?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been listening to rumors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our cars were seen together in Felton.  They're calling me an accessory to murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are.  Now. Beat.  They're stuck with each other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's several bedrooms down the hall.  Take your pick. 84  INT. BEDROOM                                                    84 The room is a strange decor.  18th century paintings hang beside grotesque medieval carvings. Brenna's face softens with worry.  What is she doing? 85  EXT. RURAL PAY PHONE - DAY                                      85 A plain-clothed POLICE OFFICER is in mid conversation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, that's the last place we saw her.  Okay, will do. He hangs up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) We keep looking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wonderful. 86  INT. FARMHOUSE - DAY                                            86 Taupin sits at his desk.  Before him is spread out blank birth certificates, driver licenses and title deeds.  His eyes lift to the corridor where Brenna is.  An idea has come to him. Brenna enters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's all that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Richard Taupin has become cumbersome.  It would be best if he just disappeared. Brenna walks to the window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You did kill those men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not all of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you finish, what then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I go my way and you can write all you want about the big bad Mr. Taupin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You make it all sound so simple.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The only real difficulty comes in changing over the ownership of property I've aquired.  That requires certain records and most importantly a personal appearance at the county seat in Gettysburg.  But that's where you come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want me to front for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The less exposure I recieve around government buildings the better.  You, as Mrs. Taupin, will attract considerably less attention than I. Brenna is unsure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not such a bad trade.  The story of a lifetime for a few days work? 87  INT. TAUPIN'S WASHINGTON TOWNHOUSE                              87 Detective Moran looks through the broken remains of the living room. An INSPECTOR enters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They lost her outside of Thurmont. Moran sighs and tosses a piece of wood on the pile of debris.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want people in here to check over every piece of this stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Figure she's with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We ran down that Church Hill info. She's right.  There is no Richard Taupin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any other I.D.s come up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet.  Called FBI yesterday. Thompson's going to try CIA this afternoon. (shrugs) Y'never know. Moran rises and dons his coat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should have seen him the first night.  Son of a bitch stood there with a quart of blood on his pant leg and didn't even blink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd think he'd had practice. Moran walks to the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think he has.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The men are assembled, Major. A GENERAL stands beside the major.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See that they are indeed ready, Dupont.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes General. 89  EXT. PARADE GROUND - DAY                                        89 A regiment of INFANTRYMEN, pale blue coat tails tossing in the light breeze, stand at attention. A STAFF SARGEANT presents the men to Dupont.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Regiment ready for review, sir. Dupont walks past the sargeant to the line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to soldier) Stand straight, you are a soldier of the King.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Yes sir. Dupont continues down the line.  Another soldier's infantry jacket is almost hilariously mis-buttoned, one collar sticking up four inches higher than the other. Dupont with both hands rips open the soldier's coat, spraying brass buttons onto the ground. He moves on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to soldier) Where is your bayonet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #3 Lost it sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where? The soldier hedges.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You heard the Major!  Where!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #3 Whorehouse sir. Dupont's face softens in exasperation, then toughens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your rifle.  Hand it to me. The soldier obeys.  Dupont inspects the firing mechanism.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The flint is cracked.  No spark will reach your powder.  You will die tomorrow. He throws the rifle roughly back into the soldier's hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow you go to _battle_!  And you look like children! (beat) The General has charged me with seeing that you are prepared, and prepared you will be!  If necessary you stand here all night!  Sargeant! The sargeant leaps to attention.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir. Dupont turns briskly, then stops abruptly as if alerted by some- thing.  He whirls around and faces the young infantrymen. His expression is quizzical as he walks the line, checking each face carefully. One PRIVATE seizes his attention.  The private is cautious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mulet. It is as if Dupont knows him.  The two stare at each other. Dupont turns and leaves. 90  INT. COTTAGE - EVENING                                          90 Inside a small farmhouse commandeered for officer's quarters, Dupont (Conor) and several others eat their evening meal. A CAPTAIN finishes his story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amused) ...And what a sight!  That old mare just kept falling over her own guts till someone finally shot her. The OFFICERS LAUGH.  All but Dupont.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beside Dupont) Complete your inspection?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're nothing but boys.  It will be a slaughter tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) I doubt much can change that. The enemy has five brigades waiting for us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We need more time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Won't get it. (shrugs) We are a sacrifice.  A diversion. Dupont pokes unenthusiastically at his plate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eat up Dupont.  It will probably be your last.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rises) Not likely. Dupont goes to the window.  Dusk shines orange on his face. In the foreground the man Dupont encountered at the line-up, Mulet, is chopping firewood. 91  EXT. COTTAGE - NIGHT                                            91 Several hours later. Most are asleep.  Mulet continues his wood splitting. From out of the dark cottage steps Dupont.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought I gave orders the regiment was to drill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Staff sargeant detailed me to prepare firewood for the break- fast cooking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is your position?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Second musketeer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand you joined up in Bremen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You seem to understand a great deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am a Major, Private.  You would do well remembering that when addressing me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, "sir".  I thought we spoke as equals.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Equals?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) If you wish to play games, Major. Mulet returns to his chore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait.  I think we understand each other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have no understanding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then it is time two of us did. You are very young.  I was once young.  I can help. Mulet LAUGHS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help?  I've seen others "help". Somehow a head always ended up on the counter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It can be different.  It must be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It never changes, Major. Mulet turns to his chore.  Dupont grabs his arm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes him off) Stay out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angry) Don't threaten me, Private.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disgust) Who do you think I am?  One of your freckle faced children waiting to die tomorrow?  "Threaten you"?  You and I just living will always be a threat.  Forever.  Look at your life, Major.  Look at mine.  Nothing there but threat.  Threats and nothingness. It's what we live for. Mulet turns his back on Dupont. Dupont draws his cutlass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do not turn your back on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are really going to force this, aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Either you are with me or against me. Mulet turns slowly, axe in hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have I a choice? The two stare into eyes empty of emotion. Mulet's hand flinches.  An attack? Dupont CUTS quickly, slicing open both of Mulet's arms. The axe drops to the ground. Mulet seems strangely calm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see Major?  You are not so different. Dupont cuts off Mulet's head where he stands. 92  EXT. CLEARING - NIGHT                                           92 Dupont drags the corpse across the meadow and dumps it into a swamp. 93  INT. CATHEDRAL - NIGHT                                          93 It is very late.  Only a few OFFICERS are seated in the pews. Dupont tries to concentrate on prayer, but is distracted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (voice flashback) You see Major?  You are not so different...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had no choice. Dupont sighs and looks to the altar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who am I deceiving?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly not me. Dupont whirls around to see the Knight, dressed as he in uniform, sitting one row behind. Dupont leaps to his feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You needn't look so flushed, Major.  You are quite safe in church. Dupont eases his breathing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: State of grace and all that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tradition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all we have. Dupont has backed up a few paces.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All this time and still a scared little boy. Dupont sits down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not so scared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps not. (smiles) You seem to have misplaced a private.  No doubt by now his head is stranger to his neck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No doubt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You surprise me.  Eliminating a rival like that.  Such are the actions of a man of conquest.  I was mistaken.  300 years have turned the boy's fear into ambit- ion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you very well, Conor MacLeod. And I can see the truth beginning to make itself clear to you.  Mulet, Romirez, they were fools without vision.  It was destined that the board would be cleared for the real players. The Knight almost seems proud of Dupont.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Romirez understood.  Not you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Romirez is dust. The Knight looks to the altar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finish your prayers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finish yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Our common heritage. (beat) I am your only real friend, you know.  The only one who truly understands you. (rises) I look forward to the day we meet again.  And I kill you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So sure? The Knight leans forward and puts his face very near.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't stay in church forever. The Knight moves into the aisle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, Major. He exits. Conor sits in the dim church alone.  Very alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Morning Mr. North
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Such a pretty day.  If I live to be 90 I'll never tire of mornings like this.  Mind you I'm 74 now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Yes sir.  When you get older your priorities change.  It's the simple things that count.  Without them growing old can be a very lonely thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure that's true. The grandson is having difficulty baiting his line.  Taupin bends down beside the young fisherman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (takes worm) Here.  The hook should go just below the head, where the meat is toughest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. Taupin's show of affection surprises Brenna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show you a trick. Taupin takes a clump of leaves from the bridge and winds them around the hook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fish are creatures of habit.  They like their food where they're used to it.  At the top, hiding in old leaves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where did you learn that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father taught me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your father must be smart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, he was. Brenna is touched. 96  INT. TAUPIN'S FARMHOUSE - NIGHT                                 96 Brenna lies on her bed thinking.  She puts on a robe and walks into the living room. LIVING ROOM Taupin sits before the fireplace, its flames reflecting on his brandy glass.  Brenna moves quietly to a seat beside him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eyes on the fireplace) There was a man once.  Just a simple woodcarver.  But he understood.  More than anyone he could see to the heart of it. (beat) It never ends.  Today is the same as the first.  Tomorrow will be the same as today.  So much time.  And all of it wasted. (beat) You love history?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish I could. 97  INT. CITY HALL                                                  97 Brenna looks through a property zoning book. 98  EXT. WORSTICK MAIN STREET - DAY                                 98 Walking past small town stores, Brenna allows herself a moment to window shop. IN A SHOP WINDOW Is a small poster advertising a community get-together.  Brenna peels it off the glass and slips it into her notebook. 99  INT. TAUPIN'S FARMHOUSE                                         99 Brenna and Taupin go over various forms and documents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The estate stuff is pretty straight forward.  Just lots of forms and an appearance at the county seat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It will take some time for the forms to clear before you go to Gettysburg. Brenna is silent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Second thoughts? Pause.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. (beat) So what now?  We just wait?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, as long as we're stuck here. She hands him the poster from earlier.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's some sort of party the town is throwing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They do it each year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought it might be a nice break from all of this. Taupin stacks the documents into a folder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe it would do us both good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a catch.  You're supposed to wear 19th century clothing. 100  INT. FARMHOUSE CELLAR                                         100 Taupin is going through an old trunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father was something of a junk collector. He comes across a long period dress and offers it to Brenna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, try this.  I suppose they're still making women the same as back then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A little dusty. Taupin fishes through the trunk and comes up with an old top hat.  He turns it over in his hand with stoic memory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do it again. She is thoroughly charmed by Conor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. Conor wraps a length of yarn about his fingers.  By turning his hand over and bending his knuckles just so, the web becomes the outline of a lion..
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A lion. (growls) Katherine is delighted. Conor starts to remove the yarn.  Katherine touches his arm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh please.  Another one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What would you like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something pretty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like you. Conor cups his hands, bends his fingers, and comes up with a four leaf clover.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's wonderful.  Where did you ever learn it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Far away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kiss me. Conor shoots a glance for the mother, then kisses Katherine softly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (o.s.) You'll be leaving the girl alone. A YOUNG MAN stands a few yards from the stairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: David.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have cause to bothering us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's my girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: David, we've already spoken of this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not what he pretends to be. Conor climbs to his feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You best leave, son.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think you're so high and mighty, coming into town and taking a man's woman.  Well I know about you.  I know about the things you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (moving closer) I said you best leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd like that, wouldn't you? (to Katherine) Ask him about his friends.  The ones he meets in the town square. Ask him about the blade he keeps beneath his bed. Conor grabs the youth's collar and pulls him close.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (like ice) Leave.  While you still can. The youth pushes away from the grasp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't frighten me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should. The young man throws a fist at Conor.  It is easily blocked. Conor returns with a savage blow to the chest that knocks the young man gasping onto the ground. Katherine runs up behind and grabs Conor's outstretched arm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!  Leave him.  Please don't hurt him. Please. COUGHING painfully, the youth climbs to his feet and staggers away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not what you think. He turns and runs down the road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not what you think! Katherine turns to Conor, his face still locked in ice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't care who you are or where you come from. She hugs him tightly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you. Conor's face softens as he brings up an arm to hold her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Mr. Taupin!  Glad you could make it. Best get some punch before it's gone.  Near the whole valley showed up. They go to the table. Taupin pours a glass of punch.  An ELDERLY WOMAN approaches him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I didn't know better I'd say William Taupin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His son.  Richard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Mr. Taupin is up from Washington to look over his father's estate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your father died some years ago. This is your first visit? The tone is snide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of sorts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose a Taupin had to show up eventually. (walks away)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, Mrs. Butler. She turns in surprise at his knowing her name, then walks on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was all that about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Sorry Mr. Taupin.  That's not meant for you.  Just some didn't take much to your father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father was never one for social whirls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . TAUPIN Kept to himself for sure.  Then with all that business in '31.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What business?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Family down the road from the Taupin place was murdered.  All cut up they were.  Horrible.  Two strangers were also found with the bodies.  No one ever accused William, but with his reputation as a loner and the rumors about him and some of the wives in town, folks just never forgot.  Most were relieved when they heard he'd died.  Sorry Mr. Taupin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing to be sorry about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORTH Just your pappy scared some. The rock band finished as a PORTLY MAN in a union soldier's uniform takes the microphone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, the kids have had their fun.  Now it's time for a little more traditional dancing. The rock band gives ground to a group of older MUSICIANS.  With a nod from the union soldier they begin a folk tune with fiddles and hammer dulcimer. The costumed guests take to the floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know any of these.  I'll make a fool of myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Follow me. Taupin starts into it with perfect grace.  A faltering Brenna tries to keep up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: William Taupin seems to have left his mark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you are William Taupin, aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. They do a final turn and finish.  The other DANCERS applaud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're using your son's name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  Just the child of some lonely girl I gave a ride to.  When they died I put them in a grave with my name on it. Twenty years later I became the son. Brenna is staring at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: More punch? He leads her to a table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you must be at least
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: years old.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's impossible. Several of the ELDERLY WOMEN are watching Taupin from across the room. 103  EXT. BUS STATION - NIGHT                                      103 A bus with "Gettysburg" across the front pulls to a stop at a dark terminal.  A lone passenger steps off into the mist. It is the Knight, bound up in a leather jacket and carrying only a long, narrow case. 104  EXT. - NIGHT                                                  104 Brenna and Taupin walk alone in the night outside the hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's frightening sometimes the way you talk about other people's lives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A factor of age.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope I never get that old.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't. Brenna pulls away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must be insane.  Leaving work, ditching cops.  All to follow a murderer.  A very old murderer, but a murderer just the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been telling myself it's the award winning journal article I'm going to write.  But it's not. (looks at him squarely) It's you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not even sure why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hardly a reason to run off with a murderer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My life has been chock full of people with complications and weak- nesses.  I can't stand it.  But you're different.  It's in your hands.  A clarity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are a very perceptive young woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a little crazy. A thoughtful pause.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Cartwright, it's time I showed you something. 105  INT. FARMHOUSE CELLAR                                         105 Taupin and Brenna descend the stairs to a seemingly flush wall. Taupin reaches behind a bookcase and pulls something.  A press from his hand and the wall becomes a doorway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gestures to interior) Miss Cartwright? Brenna steps uneasily into the darkness.  Taupin follows and switches on the light. 106  INT. HIDDEN ROOM                                              106 Brenna's expression changes to awe. The room is massive, a cross between a museum and an old attic. Suits of armor, Italian statuettes, Czech ironworks, Persian fetishes and a thousand other oddities from a hundred eras crowd the shelving and floor space. The room has the look of ownership, as if civilization had taken the time to keep a scrapbook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My God. The sight is overwhelming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had this room built some time ago. Brenna picks up a Carolingian tapestry and runs her hand along its intricate weaving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That would be difficult to explain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like you to try. Taupin picks up a Byzantine icon, brushing the dust from its shoulders.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was born Conor MacLeod in the village of Ardvrek on the High- land plain of Strathnaver in the clan of MacLeod under the King of Scotland.  On the eleventh of December, 1408. He replaces the icon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have served in the armies of twelve nations, married nine women, fathered thirty-eight children and buried them all. Taupin walks along the cases.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I carried that rifle in World War I.  This book is a 16th Century policy report for the King of Austria.  The diploma is my con- ference of degree in Latin from Trinity College.  Class of 1672. (beat) It goes on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why Smith called you MacLeod.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He knows about you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is older than I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What could possibly be worth all this murder and distruction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes I think it's just for something to do.  A conquest to be the last.  Something to hold onto while everything else around you withers and blows away.  Some- thing to replace the love that can never work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's insane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps.  There is something more. An inheritance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of bodies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't kill the watchman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You killed those other two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about that family in '31?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes innocents become involved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You and your buddy make a real team, don't you?  Exchanging eloquent threats in iambic pen- tameter while hacking up all the innocents in between.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are differences.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You kill with your left hand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't killed _you_.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that a threat? Taupin moves very close.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Brenna's face softens.  She turns away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come here, Brenna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn you. He kisses her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May God commend into his kingdom the soul of our dear departed Jason, son of Katherine- The old woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And brother to Howard and James- The two middle aged sons. CONOR Watches the funeral quietly at a distance. THE OLD WOMAN As the minister continues allows her gaze to wander.  She sees Conor standing at the treeline.  Her eyes crinkle in disbelief. Releasing herself from her sons, she hobbles toward Conor. Confused, the brothers watch their mother leave the ceremony. CONOR Watches the woman approach but decides against moving. She stops a few paces away and looks over him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Katherine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I owe him this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He never knew you. The two sons come up behind.  The three stand there: an old woman who could be 60 years Conor's senior and her two sons old enough to be his father.
